text:
Hi!
I want to generate ssh private and public key with name "ctlab" in ~/.ssh directory and eval it. How to do it?

I'll help you generate SSH keys and add them to the SSH agent. Here's the step-by-step process:

```bash
# 1. Generate the SSH key pair
ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -f ~/.ssh/ctlab

# 2. Start the SSH agent in the background
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"

# 3. Add the private key to the SSH agent
ssh-add ~/.ssh/ctlab
```

After running these commands:
- The private key will be saved as `~/.ssh/ctlab`
- The public key will be saved as `~/.ssh/ctlab.pub`
- The key will be loaded into your SSH agent

If you want to see the contents of your public key (to copy it to a service like GitHub), you can use:
```bash
cat ~/.ssh/ctlab.pub
```

Make sure to set the correct permissions:
```bash
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/ctlab
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/ctlab.pub
```
How to write not a device name at the end of the key, but work email?
To add your email address to the SSH key, you can modify the ssh-keygen command like this:

```bash
ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -f ~/.ssh/ctlab -C "your.email@work.com"
```

For example, if your work email is john.doe@company.com:
```bash
ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -f ~/.ssh/ctlab -C "john.doe@company.com"
```

The `-C` flag adds a comment to the end of the public key, which is typically used for identification purposes. This doesn't affect the functionality of the key, it just helps identify which key belongs to whom when managing multiple keys.

Then continue with the same steps as before:
```bash
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
ssh-add ~/.ssh/ctlab
```

You can verify the email is attached to the key by viewing the public key:
```bash
cat ~/.ssh/ctlab.pub
```
